abstract.text: A specialized view that creates, configures, and displays Metal objects.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The
class provides a default implementation of a Metal-aware view that you can use to render graphics using Metal and display them onscreen. When asked, the view provides a
object that points at a texture for you to render new contents into. Optionally, an
can create depth and stencil textures for you and any intermediate textures needed for antialiasing. The view uses a
to manage the Metal drawable objects.
The view requires a
object to manage the Metal objects it creates for you. You must set the
property and, optionally, modify the view’s drawable properties before drawing.
The MTKView class supports three drawing modes:
Timed updates: The view redraws its contents based on an internal timer. In this case, which is the default behavior, both
and
are set to
. Use this mode for games and other animated content that’s regularly updated.
Draw notifications: The view redraws itself when something invalidates its contents, usually because of a call to
or some other view-related behavior. In this case, set
and
to
. Use this mode for apps with a more traditional workflow, where updates happen when data changes, but not on a regular timed interval.
Explicit drawing: The view redraws its contents only when you explicitly call the
method. In this case, set
to
and
to
. Use this mode to create your own custom workflow.
Regardless of drawing mode, when the view needs to update its contents, it calls the
method when that method has been overridden by a subclass, or
on the view’s delegate if the subclass doesn’t override it. You should either subclass
or provide a delegate, but not both.
In your drawing method, you obtain a render pass descriptor from the view, render into it, and then present the associated drawable.

content.text: Obtaining a Drawable from a MetalKit View

inlineContent.text: Each
is backed by a
. In your renderer, implement the
protocol to interact with a MetalKit view. Call the MetalKit view’s
property to obtain a render pass descriptor configured for the current frame:

code: // BEGIN encoding your onscreen render pass.
// Obtain a render pass descriptor generated from the drawable's texture.
// If there's a valid render pass descriptor, use it to render to the current drawable.
// BEGIN encoding your onscreen render pass.
// Obtain a render pass descriptor generated from the drawable's texture.

inlineContent.text: When you read this property, Core Animation implicitly obtains a drawable for the current frame and stores it in the

property. It then configures a render pass descriptor to draw into that drawable, including any depth, stencil, and antialiasing textures as necessary. The view configures this render pass using the default store and load actions. You can adjust the descriptor further before using it to create a
Obtain drawables as late as possible; preferably, immediately before encoding your onscreen render pass.
After rendering the contents, you must present the drawable to update the view’s contents. The most convenient way to present the content is to call the
method on the command buffer. Then, call the
method to submit the command buffer to a GPU:

code: // END encoding your onscreen render pass.
// Finalize your onscreen CPU work and commit the command buffer to a GPU.
// If there's a valid render pass descriptor, use it to render to the current drawable.
// END encoding your onscreen render pass.
// Finalize your onscreen CPU work and commit the command buffer to a GPU.

inlineContent.text: When a command queue schedules a command buffer for execution, the drawable tracks all render or write requests on itself in that command buffer. The operating system doesn’t present the drawable onscreen until the commands have finished executing. By asking the command buffer to present the drawable, you guarantee that presentation happens after the command queue has scheduled this command buffer. Don’t wait for the command buffer to finish executing before registering the drawable’s presentation.

For better performance, only retrieve the render pass descriptor when you’re ready to render the contents, and hold onto it and the related drawable object as little as possible. Release it as soon as you finish with it. For more information, see

abstract.text: Overridden by subclasses to draw the view’s image within the specified rectangle.
Submits the command buffer to run on the GPU.
Presents a drawable as early as possible.
The main Metal interface to a GPU that apps use to draw graphics and run computations in parallel.
An interface that encodes a render pass into a command buffer, including all its draw calls and configuration.
A group of render targets that hold the results of a render pass.
A Core Animation layer that Metal can render into, typically displayed onscreen.
A Core Animation layer that Metal can render into, typically displayed onscreen.
Marks the receiver’s entire bounds rectangle as needing to be redrawn.
A false value.
A true value.
Build Metal apps quicker and easier using a common set of utility classes.
A specialized view that creates, configures, and displays Metal objects.
A Boolean value that controls whether to resize the drawable as the view changes size.
The color to use to clear the color target when creating a render pass descriptor.
The depth value to use to clear the depth target when creating a render pass descriptor.
The stencil value to use to clear the stencil target when creating a render pass descriptor.
The color pixel format for the current drawable’s texture.
The color space of the rendered content.
The drawable to use for the current frame.
A render pass descriptor to draw into the current drawable.
The view’s delegate.
The texture usage characteristics that the view uses when creating the depth and stencil textures.
The format used to generate the
object.
The storage mode that the packed depth and stencil texture use.
A packed depth and stencil texture associated with the current drawable object’s texture.
The device object the view uses to create its Metal objects.
Redraws the view’s contents immediately.
The current size of drawable textures.

A Boolean value that determines whether the drawable’s textures are used only for rendering.
Initializes a view from data in a given unarchiver.
Initializes a view with the specified frame rectangle and Metal device.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the draw loop is paused.
The texture usage characteristics that the view uses when creating multisample textures.
The multisample color sample texture to render into.
The device object that the system recommends using for this view.
The recommended dimensions of the drawable.
The rate at which the view redraws its contents.

Methods for responding to a MetalKit view’s drawing and resizing events.
Draws the view’s contents.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
